text: [Music]
hey guys it's lace and welcome back to
my cupcake addiction today and we're
gonna be making a huge chocolate bar
cake so it looks like a massive
chocolate bar but it's actually cake and
way easier to make than you think let's
get started I'm using a store-bought
vanilla sponge cake so these guys are
about eight inches by six inches by just
one inch high so you don't want them any
higher than about an inch and of course
you can make them yourself if you like
I've got a bowl and I've got some
whipping cream and of course I've got
chocolate bars so I'm using her shoes
today you don't have to use Hershey's
whatever you choose so make sure it's a
really nice thin block of chocolate
nothing too thick because you're going
to need to be able to cut through this
and you don't want it to crush the cake
underneath I used 12 her sheets for the
top of my cake and I used another 8 for
my ganache I've also got an offset
spatula and a ruler you're going to need
some sort of a cake board or
presentation board so his ingredients
will make you the straight out huge
chocolate bar but if you want to
decorate it like mine you're going to
need your Hershey's template which I'll
link to down below some cornflour a
little bit of silver shimmer powder or
luster dust you need a paintbrush and
fondant in two colors so I'm using white
and chocolate brown I've also got a
knife a rolling pin and a pizza cutter
first up you wanna break your Hershey's
into a bowl and make sure that you've
unwrapped them all so you can keep your
12 best ones for the top of the cake
pour your cream over the top and then
you're gonna microwave that to make a
really nice Hershey's chocolate ganache
so you want to put it in the microwave
for 30 seconds and then give it a really
good stir and then another 30 seconds
and a really good stir until it's
beautiful and melted to resemble kind of
like a chocolate syrup
each microwave is gonna be different but
for me I found about a minute was plenty
for this mix grab your presentation
board now and you want to run a nice
line of ganache all the way along the
bottom of it for your cake to sit on
that's why I was able to lift it up at
the start of this video cuz really it's
not that tall and it's quite sturdy you
want to position three of your cake
slabs onto the board make sure they're
really nice and even and as
in the borders you can get them once
they're all on there you can spoon
generous amounts of your ganache all
over the top and you're going to use
your offset spatula to just work that
back and forth and give this cake a
really nice coat of ganache make sure
you don't leave out the sides and get
that ganache as smooth and as neat as
you can going up the sides because
they're the bits that are going to be
seen you want the top to be as level as
possible so kind of channel your in a
cement mixer here and you're going to
take your ruler and just slide it along
the top of the cake that's gonna help
you get that ganache as smooth and as
flat as you possibly can use a paper
towel or a napkin to clean up all the
way around the edges of your chocolate
bar and then you want to roughly work
out where your wrap is gonna go so if
you've got a little uneven spot or any
spots that you're not 100% happy with
make that the spot that your wrap is
gonna go over because it'll help to
cover up you want to take your Hershey's
bars now and I'm going to position them
perfectly up against the edges and you
want to just cut the block if you need
to so I'm gonna cut one of the rows off
this Hershey's lock cuz I need three and
two thirds of a Hershey's to completely
cover mine place all of your Hershey's
neatly on the top as close together as
you can and as straight and close to the
edges as you can and that essentially
makes a very very simple gigantic
chocolate bar cake now at the moment it
looks alright but it's still not
resembling a giant chocolate bar in my
opinion so we're gonna decorate it up
with a Hershey's wrapper you don't need
to do Hershey's here but I found the
logo really easy to cut around it's not
too intricate and it's not too detailed
so I will leave a link to this template
down below you just want to print it out
on an a4 sheet of paper and just cut
around the letters and don't do all the
letters here because you're only going
to do half of the wrapper so I just did
the Hirsh sprinkle down some cornflour
and I'm not gonna lie this is the most
tedious part of this whole cake it's not
hard but it is time-consuming so you
want to take your white fondant and
you're going to roll it out really nice
and thin the thinner the better and then
you just want to place your little
letters onto the fondant and cut as
neatly as you can around them I used a
regular knife but if I had have had an
exacto knife or a scalpel it actually
would have been a lot easier so there's
a tip when you're making yours if you
can cut these out and let them sit for
about half an hour before trying to put
them on the cake they're a lot easier to
work with
once all of your fondant letters are cut
out you can use just that straight
luster dust and brush all of your
letters so that they're silver just like
the Hershey's logo otherwise you can mix
that with a little bit of alcohol or
clean lemon extract so it paints on a
little bit easier let your letters sit
off to the side and dry and down goes a
bit more cornflour and we're going to
use this to roll out and now they're
relatively thin but much larger piece of
your chocolate brown fondant once you've
got a nice large piece that your
confidence gonna cover your cake you
actually want to just tear it because we
want this to look like a torn wrapper so
you don't want to cut it it has to look
kind of authentically torn so I've got
my torn edge and I'm just gonna lift up
my piece of fondant and I'm gonna
position the torn edge first going on an
angle across the chocolate bar and then
I'm kind of gonna drag it down so that
I've got enough coming over the back to
make like the little crinkled seal of
the end of the Hershey's bar once you're
happy with the positioning you can
smooth it down a bit on the top so you
can just see the outline of those
chocolate bar pieces through the center
and then use your pizza cutter to cut up
the two side edges as close as you
possibly can to the base of that cake
for your little back piece you just want
to trim it roughly along so that it's
still kind of hanging out but it's not
hanging over the edges of the board and
it's sort of squarish with the cake and
if there's any little kinks or crimps
leave them in there because they make it
look really authentic I'm actually gonna
make a few more using my knife once
you're happy with that being the little
end of your chocolate bar wrapper just
go along with the back of your knife and
make all of those little crinkled
indents and you might need to just
reposition some of your cute little
kinks now before you go positioning your
logo I actually printed out another copy
this is just so that I can get a really
good indication of where my letters are
gonna go so I'm going to place a little
skewer hole in the center of each one of
my letters that hded are and the S and
that's gonna go right through into the
fondant but it's gonna give me a really
good guide as to where I should stick my
letters down I'm simply using a little
bit of water and a paintbrush on the
back of my letters and I'm making sure
that I've got that template there so
that I can see that the little dot on my
template is exactly where I'm placing
the letter over the little dot that's
been poked through that chocolate
fondant so the logo should be almost
exactly the same as it is on the piece
of paper filled last letter you're going
to have to cut away a bit because it's
supposed to be torn so I've cut away
most of the H and I've just got a little
bit left and then to cover up any jagged
edges you're just going to take your
knife or a toothpick and just kink that
little wrapper back over the torn letter
H so that's it it's that easy you've
just made a giant chocolate bar cake
make sure you subscribe to my channel my
